Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Wave Propagation Analysis using Experimental Data for the Estimation of Central Aortic Blood Pressure using Peripheral Circulatory Signals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Central aortic blood pressure significantly better predicts cardiovascular risk than commonly used brachial artery blood pressure. However, it is not widely used in clinical practice since it is very difficult to measure. This project concerns fundamental research on mathematical modeling to enable estimation of central aortic blood pressure from as few as two non-invasive peripheral circulatory waveforms. If successful, this project will advance personalized healthcare and medical device industry sectors. In particular, it will improve the way patients with cardiovascular disease are treated via its low-cost and non-invasive method that allows better assessment of cardiovascular health and prompt detection of its impairment. It may also stimulate the medical device industry and in turn the overall economy by stimulating the development of cost-effective, deployable medical devices for cardiovascular health monitoring, which will ultimately lead to improved therapy and treatment. This project will also have broad impact on education and knowledge dissemination, by bridging the gap between engineering, systems biology and medicine, attracting women and underrepresented students to multi-disciplinary research, and broadly disseminating the knowledge gained from this project through a dedicated website.

The objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that central aortic blood pressure can be estimated from as few as two non-invasive peripheral circulatory waveforms via model-based system identification. To fulfill this objective, cardiovascular system is viewed as a nonlinear dynamic wave propagation system with unknown input. In this project, a theoretical study to develop system identification and input de-convolution methods for a class of nonlinear wave propagation systems will be conducted, and then the validity of the methods will be examined by applying them to the problem of estimating central aortic blood pressure waveform from two non-invasive peripheral circulatory waveforms. This project will contribute to advance dynamic systems and control by solving a system identification problem for a class of nonlinear dynamic systems. Since the class of systems considered belongs to cardiovascular health monitoring applications, it will advance systems physiology initiatives. Especially, this project will benefit the development of data-based modeling methods for physiologic systems and neuroscience, such as condition monitoring of cardiovascular hemodynamics and assessment of autonomic-cardiac regulation function. Ultimately, this project may open up new opportunities for technological advances in pervasive and personalized medicine, which can ultimately improve the quality of life of human beings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a suite of methodological foundations to address an important health problem of determining subject-specific heart blood pressure signal from non-invasively acquired extremity arterial pulse waveform signals.  To solve the problem involved two mathematical challenges: (i) how to determine the mathematical representation of the cardiovascular system in a subject, and (ii) how to utilize such a mathematical representation, in conjunction with the non-invasively acquired extremity arterial pulse waveform signals, to determine the (unmeasured and unknown) heart blood pressure signal.  In this project, novel generalizable methodologies were developed to solve (i) system identification problem for a class of nonlinear wave propagation systems subsuming the cardiovascular system and (ii) observer-based input de-convolution problem for a class of multi-channel dynamical systems, which are applicable to the posed health problem at hand.  The efficacy of the methodologies developed in this project was experimentally confirmed in human subjects, which suggested that the mathematical representation of the cardiovascular system in a subject as well as the heart blood pressure of the subject can be accurately determined using the non-invasively acquired arm and ankle arterial pulse waveform signals called the pulse volume recordings (PVRs) (Fig. 1 and Fig. 2).  This project also investigated how the solution to the posed health problem can potentially address cardiovascular disease diagnosis challenges and cardiovascular health monitoring challenges based on wearable devices.  The outcomes of the research activities have been disseminated in premier journals and conferences.

This project supported a number of trainees, including a post-doc (who is a faculty now), multiple PhD and MS students, and a number of undergraduate and pre-college students.  The PhD student who was primarily responsible for this project has received multiple awards, honors, and recognitions for research excellence and productivity, including a Best Paper Award from the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME).

In summary, this project created a range of new generalizable knowledge relevant to the mathematical modeling, system identification, and observer-design of a class of dynamical systems, which are applicable to the problem of determining subject-specific heart blood pressure signal from non-invasively acquired arm and ankle arterial pulse waveform signals, as well as many other applications in health.  Hence, the outcomes of this project may in the long run facilitate the development and commercialization of next-generation medical devices capable of conveniently determining the heart blood pressure in human subjects as well as others, thereby all in all stimulating the economy and human well-being.  The personnel trained in this project will grow into next-generation STEM workforce equipped with interdisciplinary knowledge on engineering, health, and medicine, who will maintain the nation?s competitiveness in the areas of science and engineering.

Modified by: Jin-Oh Hahn

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to develop a suite of methodological foundations to address an important health problem of determining subject-specific heart blood pressure signal from non-invasively acquired extremity arterial pulse waveform signals. To solve the problem involved two mathematical challenges: (i) how to determine the mathematical representation of the cardiovascular system in a subject, and (ii) how to utilize such a mathematical representation, in conjunction with the non-invasively acquired extremity arterial pulse waveform signals, to determine the (unmeasured and unknown) heart blood pressure signal. In this project, novel generalizable methodologies were developed to solve (i) system identification problem for a class of nonlinear wave propagation systems subsuming the cardiovascular system and (ii) observer-based input de-convolution problem for a class of multi-channel dynamical systems, which are applicable to the posed health problem at hand. The efficacy of the methodologies developed in this project was experimentally confirmed in human subjects, which suggested that the mathematical representation of the cardiovascular system in a subject as well as the heart blood pressure of the subject can be accurately determined using the non-invasively acquired arm and ankle arterial pulse waveform signals called the pulse volume recordings (PVRs) (Fig. 1 and Fig. 2). This project also investigated how the solution to the posed health problem can potentially address cardiovascular disease diagnosis challenges and cardiovascular health monitoring challenges based on wearable devices. The outcomes of the research activities have been disseminated in premier journals and conferences. This project supported a number of trainees, including a post-doc (who is a faculty now), multiple PhD and MS students, and a number of undergraduate and pre-college students. The PhD student who was primarily responsible for this project has received multiple awards, honors, and recognitions for research excellence and productivity, including a Best Paper Award from the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME). In summary, this project created a range of new generalizable knowledge relevant to the mathematical modeling, system identification, and observer-design of a class of dynamical systems, which are applicable to the problem of determining subject-specific heart blood pressure signal from non-invasively acquired arm and ankle arterial pulse waveform signals, as well as many other applications in health. Hence, the outcomes of this project may in the long run facilitate the development and commercialization of next-generation medical devices capable of conveniently determining the heart blood pressure in human subjects as well as others, thereby all in all stimulating the economy and human well-being. The personnel trained in this project will grow into next-generation STEM workforce equipped with interdisciplinary knowledge on engineering, health, and medicine, who will maintain the nation?s competitiveness in the areas of science and engineering.
